captions.text:
The city of Chicago is currently experiencing
a wave of violent crime unlike anything they've

seen before. People are calling it Chi-raq
and equating it to a war zone. So, what's

going on over there - and why is violent crime
escalating so quickly?

Well, there are two main narratives being
used to describe the situation. The first

one has to do with the economic and resource
issues that Chicago is currently facing, and

the second one focuses on changes within the
criminals themselves.
Now the first argument is fairly straightforward.

The city has a huge problem of segregation
along poverty lines. The poor people in Chicago

are isolated in the neighborhoods with the
fewest resources and almost no opportunities

for advancement. It's a situation that's known
to develop - and foster - a disenfranchised
criminal class.

But the city also has a population problem.
Almost 200,000 people have left Chicago since

2000, and the effects have been devastating.
Businesses are closing, the city is collecting

less in taxes, its infrastructure is crumbling,
and the middle class is leaving town quickly.

On top of that, the city just doesn't have
enough cops. Chicago is almost 1,000 officers

short of authorized strength. And due to budget
issues, they're unable to replace cops faster

than the rate at which they're retiring. So
the problem is getting worse.

But that's the narrative in pretty much any
city that has a problem with violent crime.

What makes Chicago different - is our second
narrative. The one about the criminals themselves.

Up until 1997, street crime in Chicago was
mostly run by a handful of gangs, and it was

localized in certain areas of the city. Most
of it was centered around public housing projects,

like Cabrini-Green - which was featured in
the movie Candyman.

The largest gang in Chicago was called The
Gangster Disciples, and it was run by a man

named Larry Hoover. Between the housing projects
and the power of the Gangster Disciples, crime

was reasonably contained and predictable.
It sounds wrong to say, but the power of this

one violent gang actually helped keep gang
violence under control.

Then in 1997, Hoover and the rest of the Gangster
Disciples leadership were put in jail. And

that same year, the city started demolishing
those housing projects.

As a result, gangs had no unified leadership
and no central location for their activities.

In-fighting and territory disputes started
almost immediately and every year since then,

things have gotten worse. The Gangster Disciples
have split off into numerous factions - all
competing against each other.

According to the last official estimate, there
are now over 600 different gang factions in

Chicago. They're all fighting against each
other, and they're doing it all over the city.

It's a tough situation, and unfortunately
- there doesn't appear to be an end in sight.

If you have anything you'd like us to cover,
please let us know in the comments - and if

you'd like to know more interesting stuff,
like where our real life spies come from - click

here now. And 
remember - we release new episodes 5 days
a week, so click subscribe and you can get

em all right there on your Youtube feed. Thanks
for watching.

title: Why Chicago Has So Much Gang Violence

I'm a Chicagoan. I have always lived on the gentrified, upper class north 
side, in a tier 4 neighborhood. (There are 4 tiers of neighborhoods, tier 4 
is the best, tier 1 is the worst) There is hardly any violence in my 
neighborhood, and I go to a private school with less than 15 kids per class 
in this neighborhood. Everything is safe here, but my brother still 
sometimes gets a class on "gang resistance education". (He goes to the same 
school). I'm just thinking, shouldn't we (Chicagoans) move the gang 
resistance education to the places that actually have gangs? There are no 
gangs that I know of in my neighborhood (Ravenswood by Lincoln Square). 
Test tube is right about segregation. ﻿

comments.text:
Here is what Chicago needs to do to fix the city or at least go into the 
right direction. 
1. No more projects or government housing
2. Deregulate the city to make it attractive to businesses again
3. Fix the crime situation by Implementing Community Policing, Private 
Security Companies, Legalize gun ownership, or do anything they can do to 
lower crime.
4. Fix the root of the crime problem by fixing the education situation by 
either improving their public school, embracing charter schools, and 
advertisements.
5. Control alcohol and drug drug addiction by its citizens with clinics and 
rehabilitation programs.
6. Fight Poverty with relief programs such as food stamp.
7. Build efficient and sustainable practices like community gardens, green 
energies,  traffic cams, and rebuilding the infrastructure.

These aren't the only policies or necessarily the best to fix Chicago, but 
its what I could think of off the top of my head.﻿
comments.author: Gamerad360

comments.text:
Companies would prefer to stay in the United States, unless the climate is 
very unfriendly. For a business to even consider moving wages and taxes 
must be higher than building a new factory, new wages, new taxes, import 
fees, shipping, hiring security, adjusting to a new culture, and government.

Many other states still have their industry, but Chicago suffered so badly, 
because they were dependent on only a few major industries, which they 
forced overseas. 

If industry wasn't hit so bad by taxes and wages, then Chicago wouldn't 
have lost anywhere as many jobs.

The other problem is many traditional industries in the U.S. has been on 
the decline, because of lack of quality and research and development.
comments.author: Gamerad360
